breaking_news.title: Notepad++ Update Mechanism Hijacked to Deliver Targeted Malware
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: Notepad++ released version 8.9.2 to patch a critical flaw where an advanced China-nexus threat actor hijacked the software’s update mechanism to selectively deliver malware to high-value targets. The attacker compromised the update infrastructure to inject malicious payloads only on specific systems, leveraging the trust users place in official software updates. The fix introduced a "double-lock" design requiring dual verification for update signatures, making exploitation significantly more difficult.

Paragraph 2: This supply chain compromise affects Notepad++ users globally, particularly those in government, critical infrastructure, and high-tech sectors targeted by the attacker. The selective nature of the attack suggests a focused espionage operation rather than broad criminal activity. The incident underscores the growing risk of supply chain attacks on widely used open-source tools and the need for hardened update mechanisms across the software ecosystem.
threat_actors: China-nexus threat actor (unnamed, but likely APT group)

breaking_news.title: Dell RecoverPoint Zero-Day Exploited Since Mid-2024 by UNC6201
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: A maximum-severity (CVSS 10.0) vulnerability in Dell RecoverPoint for Virtual Machines—tracked as CVE-2026-22769—was exploited as a zero-day by the China-nexus threat cluster UNC6201 since at least mid-2024. The flaw stems from hard-coded credentials in the software, enabling attackers to gain persistent remote access and deploy "ghost NICs" to evade detection. Google Mandiant and GTIG confirmed the campaign, which targets enterprise environments for long-term espionage and potential sabotage.

Paragraph 2: The compromise affects enterprise customers using Dell RecoverPoint for VM disaster recovery, including Fortune 500 companies, critical infrastructure operators, and government agencies. The long duration of exploitation (nearly two years) and stealth techniques indicate a highly sophisticated campaign aimed at strategic data access and resilience disruption. This highlights the severe risk of pre-installed credentials in security-critical infrastructure software.

breaking_news.title: Google Chromium CSS Zero-Day CVE-2026-2441 Actively Exploited
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: Google patched CVE-2026-2441, a high-severity (CVSS 8.8) use-after-free vulnerability in the Chromium CSS component, after it was actively exploited in the wild—the first Chrome zero-day of 2026. Security researcher Shaheen Fazim responsibly disclosed the flaw on February 11, 2026, and Google released emergency updates (Chrome 145.0.7632.75+) to address it. Attackers could leverage the bug to execute arbitrary code inside the Chrome sandbox via malicious webpages.

Paragraph 2: The vulnerability impacts all Chromium-based browsers (Chrome, Edge, Brave, etc.) and affects hundreds of millions of users globally. CISA added it to its KEV catalog on February 18, citing confirmed exploitation. The rapid timeline from disclosure to patch and KEV listing reflects the urgency of the threat. Given Chrome’s dominance in enterprise and consumer use, this zero-day posed widespread risk of initial access for ransomware, espionage, and credential theft campaigns.

breaking_news.title: SmartLoader Clones Oura MCP Server to Spread StealC Info-Stealer
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: The SmartLoader threat actor cloned a legitimate Oura MCP (Model Context Protocol) server—used to connect AI assistants to Oura Ring health data—to trick developers into downloading and installing the StealC infostealer. The fake project included fabricated GitHub forks, contributors, and documentation to appear credible. Once executed, the trojanized package exfiltrated developer credentials, browser passwords, and cryptocurrency wallet keys.

Paragraph 2: This supply chain attack targets AI and software development communities, exploiting trust in open-source AI infrastructure and the growing adoption of MCP. The campaign demonstrates how threat actors are weaponizing emerging AI frameworks to broaden their reach and credibility. Organizations using AI agent tooling or integrating with health-tech APIs are at elevated risk, highlighting the need for artifact integrity verification in AI development pipelines.

breaking_news.title: Keenadu Android Backdoor Preinstalled in Firmware, OTA Updates
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: Kaspersky uncovered Keenadu, a sophisticated Android backdoor embedded in device firmware during the manufacturing phase—often in counterfeit or compromised devices—and even distributed via signed OTA updates. Like Triada, it hooks into the Zygote process to infect every app launched on the device, enabling ad fraud, credential theft, and full remote control. Some variants were found in devices from brands including Alldocube, and it can persist across factory resets.

Paragraph 2: The backdoor affects millions of Android users globally, particularly those purchasing low-cost or refurbished devices. Its firmware-level persistence and OTA delivery method make detection and remediation extremely difficult, requiring reflashing or hardware replacement. This represents a new tier of mobile supply chain compromise, where attackers embed malware before devices reach consumers—posing serious risks to enterprise mobility and personal privacy.

breaking_news.title: Microsoft Copilot Bug Summarizes Confidential Emails Bypassing DLP
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: Microsoft confirmed a bug in Microsoft 365 Copilot has been summarizing confidential emails since late January, bypassing organizational data loss prevention (DLP) policies. The AI assistant was generating summaries of restricted messages—including those marked as sensitive or blocked by DLP rules—without proper access controls, exposing internal communications to unauthorized users.

Paragraph 2: The flaw impacts enterprises, government agencies, healthcare providers, and financial institutions relying on Copilot for productivity. It undermines core compliance and data governance frameworks, risking regulatory penalties and reputational damage. While not a vulnerability in the traditional sense, this logic flaw in AI integration reveals critical gaps in securing AI-assisted workflows and highlights the need for AI-specific DLP enforcement.

breaking_news.title: CISA Adds Four Actively Exploited Flaws to KEV Catalog
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: CISA added four vulnerabilities to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog on February 18, 2026, citing active exploitation: CVE-2026-2441 (Google Chromium CSS use-after-free), CVE-2020-7796 (Zimbra SSRF), CVE-2024-7694 (TeamT5 ThreatSonar unrestricted upload), and CVE-2008-0015 (Microsoft Windows ActiveX RCE). These flaws span major platforms and have been weaponized in real-world campaigns, including ransomware and espionage operations.

Paragraph 2: The KEV listing triggers mandatory patching deadlines for U.S. federal agencies and pressures enterprise defenders to prioritize remediation. CVE-2026-2441 and CVE-2020-7796 are especially concerning due to their high CVSS scores (8.8 and 9.8, respectively) and widespread deployment. This update underscores the persistent threat of unpatched legacy and modern vulnerabilities across critical infrastructure and enterprise software.

breaking_news.title: OpenClaw AI Agent Configuration Stolen by Infostealers
breaking_news.summary:
Paragraph 1: Information-stealing malware has been observed exfiltrating OpenClaw (formerly Clawdbot and Moltbot) configuration environments—including API keys, gateway tokens, and agent settings—for the first time. Hudson Rock and other researchers confirmed this shift, noting that attackers are targeting the "digital soul" of personal AI agents rather than just browser credentials. OpenClaw is an open-source framework enabling developers to build agentic AI assistants.

Paragraph 2: This marks a new threat vector: compromising AI agent identities to hijack autonomous workflows, access privileged systems, and impersonate users in AI-assisted environments. As enterprises adopt agentic AI tools for automation, attackers can leverage stolen configurations to move laterally, exfiltrate data, or disrupt operations with machine-speed precision. The incident highlights urgent risks in securing AI agent infrastructure and secrets management.
